item.title: Why_analog
item.description: The (electronic) world is going Digital, why Analog? Note: If you have a suggestion for items or links to include in this list, do not hesitate to contact P. Kinget. "The World is Analog" [P. Kinget, Circuit Cellar #292, 11/2014] (pdf) "Engineering the world through Analog" (pdf) [H. Cozanian, TI E2E Community, Analog Wire Blog, 06/2013] Fun Facts: Analog links real-world senses like hearing, touching and seeing to the digital world A typical electronic design can have 15-20 analog chips for every embedded processor An estimated 96 billion analog ICs will be sold in 2013 "

item.title: Teaching
item.description: Teaching Fall 2022: EE4312 Analog Electronic Circuits Spring 2022: EE6350 VLSI Design Lab Fall 2021: EE4312 Analog Electronic Circuits Spring 2021: EE9303 Seminar in Electronic Circuits: Advanced Topics in IC Design Fall 2020B: EE4312 Analog Electronic Circuits (Fall B section) Spring 2020: EE9303 Seminar in Electronic Circuits: Advanced Topics in IC Design Fall 2017 - Fall 2019: teaching exemption as department chair Fall 2016 - Spring 2017: On sabbatical Spring 2016: EE6350 VLSI Design Lab

S. Chatterjee, K.P. Pun, Y. Tsividis, and P. Kinget, Analog Circuit Design Techniques at 0.5V, Springer, ISBN 978-0-387-69953-0, 2007. R. Gharpurey, and P. Kinget, (Eds.), Ultra Wideband - Circuits, Transceivers and Systems, Springer, ISBN 978-0-387-37238-9, 2008. Book Chapters P.

item.title: Longer_bio2
item.description: Long Bio Peter R. Kinget received the engineering degree (Summa cum Laude) in electrical and mechanical engineering and the Ph.D. (Summa cum Laude with Congratulations of the Jury) in electrical engineering from the Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Belgium, in 1990 and 1996, respectively. From 1991 to 1995, he received a graduate fellowship from the Belgian National Fund for Scientific Research (NFWO) to work as a Research Assistant at the ESAT-MICAS of the Katholieke Universiteit Leuven.
